solution_line_template: The primer is ${primer_original_price} with 20% off so that's {primer_original_price}*{primer_discount_rate} = $<<{primer_original_price}*{primer_discount_rate}={primer_discount_amount}>>{primer_discount_amount} off

The primer is ${primer_original_price} and the discount is for ${primer_discount_amount} off so the sale price is {primer_original_price}-{primer_discount_amount} = $<<{primer_original_price}-{primer_discount_amount}={primer_sale_price_per_gallon}>>{primer_sale_price_per_gallon} per gallon

Blake needs {num_gallons_primer} gallons of primer that is ${primer_sale_price_per_gallon} a gallon so that's {num_gallons_primer}*{primer_sale_price_per_gallon} = $<<{num_gallons_primer}*{primer_sale_price_per_gallon}={total_primer_cost}>>{total_primer_cost}

He needs {num_gallons_paint} gallons of paint that cost ${paint_gallon_price} a gallon so that's {num_gallons_paint}*{paint_gallon_price} = $<<{num_gallons_paint}*{paint_gallon_price}={total_paint_cost}>>{total_paint_cost}

The primer is ${total_primer_cost} and the paint is ${total_paint_cost} so all total, he will spend {total_primer_cost}+{total_paint_cost} = $<<{total_primer_cost}+{total_paint_cost}={total_cost}>>{total_cost} on paint and primer
